node.title: At ‘Company’ and ‘Assassins,’ Praise for Stephen Sondheim
node.alt: There were tributes to Stephen Sondheim on Friday night from the stages of two of his shows, “Company” on Broadway and “Assassins” Off Broadway.
node.description: “I would ask you to sit back and luxuriate in his extraordinary words and music,” the director John Doyle said before Friday’s performance of the “Assassins” revival.
node.content: ["Hours after Stephen Sondheim\u2019s death, the director of the Broadway revival of \u201cCompany\u201d walked onstage before the curtain rose on Friday to acknowledge the news that many in the audience already knew but that some \u2014 judging by the murmurs that followed \u2014 had not yet heard.", "\u201cStephen Sondheim, so sadly, passed away in the early hours of this morning,\u201d said the director, Marianne Elliott. \u201cHe was truly the greatest artist that we, in our lifetime, possibly will ever know.\u201d", "Around the same time, 32 blocks downtown, the director of the Off Broadway musical, \u201cAssassins,\u201d walked onstage before the show with a similar mournful speech.", "\u201cToday is a sad day for the American theater,\u201d said the director, John Doyle. \u201cStephen Sondheim changed the face of the American musical, and we feel very blessed to be in this space at this time.\u201d", "It was evidence of Sondheim\u2019s long-lasting popularity that, on the day of his death, audience members lined up to see revivals for two of his musicals: \u201cCompany,\u201d a Broadway production starring Patti LuPone and Katrina Lenk, and \u201cAssassins,\u201d about the people who killed or tried to kill American presidents. Both had been delayed by the pandemic.", "With the cast of \u201cCompany\u201d standing onstage behind her at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, arms around one another\u2019s shoulders, Elliott said that Sondheim\u2019s death had been a shock to the production, whose members had gotten to know the composer and lyricist during the preparation for the revival. Even at 91 years old and with more than six decades of writing music and lyrics for Broadway behind him, Sondheim had taken an active role in the new run of the musical, which first premiered in 1970 and won six Tony Awards. The current production was a hit with critics when it debuted in London in 2019.", "\u201cHe didn\u2019t need to do that,\u201d Elliott said. \u201cBut he became the greatest enthusiast for it, and every single line of George Furth\u2019s and every single lyric we talked about, we debated, we argued, we chatted, we laughed,\u201d Elliott added, referring to the playwright.", "In this version, the central character, a bachelor with commitment issues, is played by a woman (Lenk). He had been supportive of the changes to the musical, Elliott said. \u201cHe really understood about art,\u201d she said, \u201cand he really understood about the now and why art should speak to the now.\u201d", "Right up until his death, Sondheim was both a fairly active writer and theatergoer. Earlier this month, Sondheim had traveled to Manhattan from his home in Connecticut to see these productions himself, attending the opening night of \u201cAssassins\u201d at the Classic Stage Company on Nov. 14 and a preview of \u201cCompany\u201d the next day. This week, Sondheim discussed his current project \u2014 his final musical \u2014 with The New York Times, saying, \u201cWhat else would I do with my time but write?\u201d", "Speaking to the audience at \u201cAssassins,\u201d Doyle urged the theatergoers to celebrate Sondheim\u2019s work rather than grieve.", "\u201cHe would be curious if you sat here sadly tonight,\u201d he said. \u201cI would ask you to sit back, to luxuriate in his extraordinary words and music.\u201d"]
